title: 112_hr4234
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" amends the terms of grazing permits and leases to extend the duration to 20 years. It also includes provisions for the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases. The Grazing Improvement Act of 2012 extends the duration of grazing permits and leases to 20 years and includes provisions for their renewal, transfer, and reissuance. Additionally, Title IV of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to address these issues. In this section, "current grazing management" refers to grazing in accordance with existing permits or leases, including modifications consistent with resource management plans. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System land and the Secretary of the Interior for Department of the Interior land. Grazing permits or leases issued by the Secretary of the Interior can be renewed, transferred, reissued, or are in pending processing. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior can renew, transfer, or reissue grazing permits or leases for National Forest System land. The process is governed by specific sections and acts. The Granger-Thye Act, Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act, and California Desert Protection Act of 1994 govern the renewal, transfer, or reissuance of grazing permits or leases for National Forest System land. The terms and conditions of expired permits or leases continue until the processing of the renewed permit or lease is completed. Permits or leases can be cancelled, suspended, or modified in accordance with applicable law. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer of grazing permits or leases for National Forest System land can be cancelled, suspended, or modified in accordance with applicable law. The Secretary concerned may renew or reissue the permit or lease for a term of 20 years after completion of processing, and may exclude the need for an environmental assessment. The Secretary concerned may renew or reissue grazing permits or leases for a term of 20 years after processing, and may exclude the need for an environmental assessment under certain conditions related to grazing management and compliance with land use plans. The Secretary may renew grazing permits for 20 years based on grazing management meeting objectives in land use plans or Department policies. The priority for completing environmental analyses is determined by the Secretary concerned. NEPA exemptions may apply. The Secretary determines the priority for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on environmental significance and available funding. NEPA exemptions include crossing/trailing authorizations and transfer of grazing preference. Amendments to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are made. "Sec. 405. Renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases."
